00048 /*****************************************************************************\
00049  *      File:   block_sparse_array.h
00050  *      Author: Robert Kidd and Wen-mei Hwu
00051  *      This file contains declarations for routines to manage the Pcode
00052  *      symbol table.
00053  *
00054  *      The sparse array is implemented as a doubly linked list of
00055  *      blocks that are multiples of BLOCK_SIZE elements long.  It is
00056  *      intended to efficiently store small clusters of data at widely
00057  *      separated indices.
00058  *
00059  *      Block size is variable, but must be a multiple of BLOCK_SIZE.  As
00060  *      the array grows, adjacent blocks are merged to keep the length of
00061  *      the list down.
00062  *
00063  *      All access functions (get/set and relatives) take a double pointer
00064  *      to a BlockSparseArray structure as the argument.  If the function
00065  *      has to search through the list for a block, it updates the pointer
00066  *      to point to that block.  Subsequent accesses to elements in that
00067  *      block will take constant time.
00068  *
00069 \*****************************************************************************/
00070 
00071 #ifndef _LIBRARY_SPARSE_ARRAY_H_
00072 #define _LIBRARY_SPARSE_ARRAY_H_
00073 
00074 #include <config.h>
00075 #include <stdio.h>
00076 
00077 /* The minimum size of a block in the array. */
00078 #define BLOCK_SIZE 32
00079 
00080 /* Flags for the options bitfield. */
00081 /* Warn if the old value in the array is non-zero when writing a new value.
00082  * This can help catch memory leaks in pointer arrays. */
00083 #define BSA_WARN_ON_OVERWRITE  0x0000000000000001
00084 /* Check that every entry in the array is zero when freeing and warn about
00085  * non-zero entries.  This can help catch memory leaks in pointer arrays. */
00086 #define BSA_CHECK_NULL_ON_FREE 0x0000000000000002
00087 
00088 /* Convert an arbitrary index and length to the values that a block
00089  * can use (multiples of BLOCK_SIZE). */
00090 
00091 /* Pad index i to a block boundary. */
00092 /* If block size is known to be a power of two, you could do something like
00093  *   i - (i % BLOCK_SIZE) */
00094 #define BSA_BLOCK_INDEX(i)     (i) - ((i) % BLOCK_SIZE)
00095 
00096 /* Pad length l from index i to a block boundary.
00097  * If block size is known to be a power of two, you could do something like
00098  *   (BLOCK_SIZE - ((i + l - 1) & (~0 >> (64-BLOCK_SIZE))) + l - 1 + \
00099  *      i - BSA_BLOCK_INDEX(i) */
00100 #define BSA_BLOCK_LENGTH(i, l) (BLOCK_SIZE - (((i) + (l) - 1) % BLOCK_SIZE) + \
00101                                 (l) - 1 + ((i) % BLOCK_SIZE))
00102 
00103 typedef struct _BlockSparseArray
00104 {
00105   int first_index;
00106   int length;
00107   long long options;
00108   struct _BlockSparseArray *next;
00109   struct _BlockSparseArray *prev;
00110   void **data;
00111 }
00112 _BlockSparseArray, *BlockSparseArray;
00113 
00114 extern BlockSparseArray NewBlockSparseArray ();
00115 extern void FreeBlockSparseArray (BlockSparseArray array);
00116 
00117 extern void BlockSparseArraySet (BlockSparseArray *array, int index,
00118                                  void *data);
00119 extern void BlockSparseArrayClear (BlockSparseArray *array, int index);
00120 extern void *BlockSparseArrayGet (BlockSparseArray *array, int index);
00121 
00122 /* Returns the index of the first element in the array.  Returns -1 if there
00123  * are no elements. */
00124 extern int BlockSparseArrayGetFirstIndex (BlockSparseArray *array);
00125 /* Returns the index of the next element after the given index.  Returns -1
00126  * if the given index is the last element. */
00127 extern int BlockSparseArrayGetNextIndex (BlockSparseArray *array, int index);
00128 /* Returns the index of the first non-zero element in the array.  Returns -1
00129  * if there is no non-zero element. */
00130 extern int BlockSparseArrayGetFirstNonZeroIndex (BlockSparseArray *array);
00131 /* Returns the index of the next non-zero element after the given index.
00132  * Returns -1 if the given index is the last non-zero. */
00133 extern int BlockSparseArrayGetNextNonZeroIndex (BlockSparseArray *array,
00134                                                 int index);
00135 
00136 /* Returns the first non-zero element in the array.  Updates the index argument
00137  * to be the index of this element.  Returns NULL (and sets index to -1) if
00138  * there are no non-zero elements. */
00139 extern void *BlockSparseArrayGetFirstNonZero (BlockSparseArray *array,
00140                                               int *index);
00141 /* Returns the next non-zero element after the given index.  Updates the
00142  * index argument to be the index of this element.  Returns NULL (and sets
00143  * index to -1) if there are no more non-zero elements. */
00144 extern void *BlockSparseArrayGetNextNonZero (BlockSparseArray *array,
00145                                              int *index);
00146 
00147 extern void BlockSparseArraySetOption (BlockSparseArray array, int option);
00148 extern void BlockSparseArrayClrOption (BlockSparseArray array, int option);
00149 
00150 /* Prepare the array for several set operations.  This will pre-allocate
00151  * a block for the needed indices.  Calling this function before a series
00152  * of sets to closely spaced indices will improve efficiency. */
00153 extern void BlockSparseArrayPrepare (BlockSparseArray *array, int index,
00154                                      int length);
00155 /* Remove extraneous blocks (blocks that contain all NULLs).  Sets array
00156  * to the first block in the list. */
00157 extern void BlockSparseArrayCompact (BlockSparseArray *array);
00158 
00159 extern void BlockSparseArrayDump (BlockSparseArray array, FILE *out,
00160                                   void (*print_func)(FILE *out, void *data));
00161 
00162 #endif
